title: 103_hr5159
content:
The Capital Budget Commission Act of 1994 establishes a commission called the Capital Budget Commission to address infrastructure needs and funding limitations. The Commission's duties include evaluating what should be included in a capital budget. The Capital Budget Commission will study and evaluate what should be included in a capital budget for the US Government, focusing on investments that sustain growth. They will submit preliminary and final reports with findings, conclusions, and recommendations on implementing capital budgeting, prioritizing items, and determining accounting methods. The Capital Budget Commission will study possible changes in the executive and legislative branches to facilitate the implementation of a capital budget. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 15 members appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment:
- 3 members appointed by the President
- 3 members appointed by the President pro tempore of the Senate
- 3 members appointed by the minority leader of the Senate
- 3 members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives
- 3 members appointed by the minority leader of the House of Representatives The Commission members, excluding Members of Congress, must have expertise in capital budgeting. If a member appointed as a Member of Congress leaves office, they can remain on the Commission for up to 60 days. Each Commission member serves for the duration of the Commission's existence, with vacancies filled as per original appointment methods. The Commission members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. 8 members constitute a quorum, with the Chairperson elected by a majority. Meetings are called by the Chairperson. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Chairperson may appoint additional staff and set their pay, exempt from certain civil service laws regarding appointments and pay rates. The Commission may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding GS-18 of the General Schedule. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission is granted powers under Section 7. The Commission under Section 7 has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain official data from US departments or agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and use the US mails. Administrative support services can be requested. The Commission has the authority to request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis to carry out its responsibilities under the Act. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

The Commission must submit a preliminary report to the President and Congress within 12 months of all members being appointed, and a final report within 18 months. 

SEC. 9. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end 30 days after submitting the final report.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funds for this Act must be appropriated in advance.
